t

The next day after he landed his men in
e mor-

e cutting of
e dicke to-
wardes
Bridawe:
as also
e building of a fort,
uppon
e point of

Stelhoven
: Where he was shotte at from
e towne,
when also there issued some fewe,
at skirmished
w
t
his people. But nothing of moment was per-
fourmed of either side. The ennemie in those
quarters is very strong, and, as it is thought, will
offer very largely, to buy
e towne: as he hath done
heeretofore, promising 60 monethes pay to every
souldier. Whiche for mine owne part, conside-
ring what I heare of
e desperat disposition,
and over dissolute courses of those souldiers, I
dout, if they can, they will rather accept, then
yeld obedience to
e states. I have talked
w
t
a couple, that are come from
e towne, since
e states arrival, who left them then at a reso-
lute point, If
e siege continued, to putte out all
e Burghers, to make their provision last longer;
or if that should faile, ether to calle in
e ennemie
or to fight it out to
e uttermost. At
sundrie times, since my imploiment in this service,
I have offered heere publickly at
e Councell table,
fol.113v

Barnevelt
and others, that if
that if

her

tie

endevo
r

ment. Howbeit they have rather chosen this vio-
lent proceeding, as being persuaded, whiche is
heere so evident, as nothing more, that all is done
in Gertrudenbergh, w
t

ties

We have receaved in Councell
a letter of excuse from Count
Maurice, for that we were not made privy to that enterprise.
His reasons were suche shiftes, as they
were scorned of all, and are not worthy
e rehersall to yo
r

t

r
John I send herew
t

e others of
e
Captaines, were in dutche, as likewise
e Countes, contening no mater of worth.
For
e Countes letter is tedious, full of
ordinary persuasions, to cause them to yeld,
and to forsake S
r
John, as a forrener and
straunger, by whom they should not suffer themselves to be directed.
